0.text:
I am so proud to be standing here in front
of you today – back in government…

9.text:
…and not just any government – a majority
Conservative Government.

16.text:
To the people in this hall, I want to say
thank you.

23.text:
You are the greatest team a Prime Minister
could ever have.

27.text:
And to the British people:
When you put your cross in the Conservative

32.text:
box, you were putting your faith in us.
To finish the job we started. To back working

39.text:
people. To deliver security for you and your
family.

42.text:
And I’ll tell you now: we will not let you
down.

57.text:
But just for a moment, think back to May 7th.
I don’t know about you, but it only takes

63.text:
two words to make me smile. Exit poll.
And then what happened that night:

71.text:
The Conservatives, winning across Wales; on
the march in the Midlands.

75.text:
Bolton West, Derby North, Berwick, Wells – Conservative
once more…

80.text:
…Gower for the first time ever.
The North, more Tory; the South, the East,

86.text:
almost a clean sweep…
…and Cornwall – that wonderful county

90.text:
– 100 per cent Conservative.
As dawn rose, a new light – a bluer light

105.text:
– fell across our isles.
And I will never forget that morning. Getting

110.text:
back to London. Seeing many of you. Then sitting
down in the flat at No10 with Sam and the

118.text:
kids getting ready for school.
There we were, surrounded by half-packed boxes

125.text:
and bin bags. Well, you have to be ready for
anything.

130.text:
I was writing my speech and preparing to go
and see Her Majesty. And I thought… I’ll

136.text:
just lie down and let it all sink in.
As I shut my eyes, Ed Balls had gone. And

144.text:
when I woke up and I switched on the radio,
Nigel Farage had gone too.

150.text:
There was a brief moment when I thought it
was all a dream.

155.text:
But there’s a serious point.
Why did all the pollsters and the pundits

165.text:
get it so wrong?
Because, fundamentally, they didn’t understand

170.text:
the people who make up our country.
The vast majority of people aren’t obsessives,

176.text:
arguing at the extremes of the debate.
Let me put it as simply as I can: Britain

181.text:
and Twitter are not the same thing.
The British people are decent, sensible, reasonable…

194.text:
…and they just want a government that supports
the vulnerable, backs those who do the right

198.text:
thing and helps them get on in life.
Good jobs; a decent home; better childcare;

205.text:
controlled immigration; lower taxes so there’s
more money at the end of the month…

209.text:
…an NHS that’s there for them, 7 days
a week; great schools; dignity in retirement…

214.text:
…that is what people want and that is what
we will deliver.

218.text:
The party of working people, the party for
working people – today, tomorrow, always.

230.text:
PARTY CHANGE
Ten years ago, I stood on a stage just like

238.text:
this one and said if we changed our party
we could change our country.

244.text:
We’ve done that – together.
I didn’t campaign on the NHS alone – you

249.text:
joined me.
It wasn’t just me who put social justice,

253.text:
equality for gay people, tackling climate
change, and helping the world’s poorest

258.text:
at the centre of the Conservative Party’s
mission – we all did.

262.text:
And I didn’t select our candidates – it
was you.

266.text:
Look who was elected in May.
Nusrat Ghani, whose parents, just a generation

273.text:
ago, were living in a small village in Kashmir.
Seema Kennedy, who was five when she and her

279.text:
family were forced to flee revolutionary Iran.
Five years ago, Johnny Mercer was on his third

287.text:
tour of duty in Afghanistan. Caught in an
ambush, he was left cradling a dear comrade

293.text:
as he lay fatally wounded.
Just days before the election, Scott Mann

301.text:
was doing his postal round in Cornwall – delivering
not just his own campaign leaflets, but his

312.text:
rivals’ too.
Different journeys, often difficult journeys,

326.text:
all leading here.
So let us hear it for them now – the new

330.text:
generation of Conservative MPs.
Round the cabinet table, a third of my colleagues

353.text:
are women.
A few months ago, we were discussing childcare.

358.text:
It was introduced by the Black British son
of a single parent, Sam Gyimah.

364.text:
He was backed up by the daughter of Gujarati
immigrants who arrived in our country from

369.text:
East Africa with nothing except the clothes
they stood up in, Priti Patel…

374.text:
…and the first speaker was Sajid Javid,
whose father came here from Pakistan to drive

380.text:
the buses.
This is what we’ve done together.

384.text:
And now with couples married because of us…
…working people backed because of us…

389.text:
…the NHS safe because of us…
…and children in the poorest parts of the

392.text:
world saved because of us…
…everyone in this hall can be incredibly

396.text:
proud of our journey – the journey of the
modern, compassionate, One Nation Conservative

408.text:
GREATER BRITAIN
So as five years of government stretch out

422.text:
before us, what do I see on the skyline?
I love Britain. I love our history and what

429.text:
we’ve given to the world.
I love our get-up-and-go; that whenever we’re

434.text:
down, we’re never out.
I love our character; our decency; our sense

439.text:
of humour.
I love every part of our country. England,

443.text:
Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland – we are
one nation and I will defend our Union with

449.text:
everything I have got.
Every day, in every way, Great Britain lives

466.text:
up to its name.
And I know this: we can make it greater still.

471.text:
A Greater Britain. Where people have greater
hope, greater chances, greater security.

478.text:
I really believe we’re on the brink of something
special in our country.

482.text:
This year, we’ve seen more people in work
than at any time in our history…

486.text:
…more of our children starting university
than ever before…

490.text:
…more British entrepreneurs setting up shop
than anywhere else in Europe.

496.text:
Wages are rising. Hope is returning. We’re
moving into the light.

501.text:
But we’re not there yet.
We’re only half way through.

506.text:
For me, that has a very literal meaning.
I can say something today that perhaps no

513.text:
Prime Minister has ever really been able to
say before.

518.text:
I’m starting the second half of my time
in this job.

523.text:
As you know, I am not going to fight another
election as your leader. So I don’t have

529.text:
the luxury of unlimited time.
Let me tell you: I am in just as much of a

534.text:
hurry as five years ago.
Securing our country, growing our economy;

540.text:
jobs, exports, growth, infrastructure…
…these are the stepping stones on the path

545.text:
to greatness for our country – and we’ve
been laying them every day since we came to

550.text:
office.
We will continue to do so.

553.text:
But to make Britain greater, we need to tackle
some deep social problems…

559.text:
…problems we only just made a start on,
as we focused on the economic emergency that

564.text:
faced us.
The scourge of poverty.

567.text:
The brick wall of blocked opportunity.
The shadow of extremism – hanging over every

572.text:
single one of us.
A Greater Britain doesn’t just need a stronger

576.text:
economy – it needs a stronger society.
And delivering this social reform is entirely

583.text:
fitting with the great history of the Conservative
Party…

586.text:
…who have always been the optimists, the
agents of hope and the leaders of change.

591.text:
That’s why I joined it.
That’s why I wanted to lead it.

595.text:
And now, in my final term as Prime Minister,
I say: let’s live up to the greatest traditions

606.text:
CONSERVATIVE VALUES
In all the challenges we face, we will be

618.text:
guided by our Conservative values.
Our belief in strong defence and sound money.

625.text:
Our belief in an enterprise economy…
…that if you set free the ambition that

629.text:
burns so deeply within the British people,
they will strike out on their own, take on

634.text:
new workers, take on the world.
Our belief in equality of opportunity, as

640.text:
opposed to equality of outcome…
…not everyone ending up with the same exam

645.text:
results, the same salary, the same house – but
everyone having the same shot at them.

650.text:
Now some people may argue these things are
obvious.

657.text:
I have to tell you, they’re not.
It becomes clearer by the day that the Labour

662.text:
Party has completely abandoned any notion
of these ideas.

668.text:
So let us resolve here, at this conference,
to do what we’ve always done: to prove our

674.text:
Conservative truths…
…to save Britain from the danger of Labour…

678.text:
…and to rebuild Britain so it is greater
still.

681.text: A Greater Britain – that is our goal.

690.text:
NATIONAL SECURITY
It begins by making the case for strong defence.

702.text:
My first duty as Prime Minister is to keep
people safe.

707.text:
Some of the loneliest moments in this job
are when you are reading intelligence reports

712.text:
about plots being planned against the British
people.

716.text:
This summer I was told that Reyaad Khan and
Junaid Hussain were in Syria planning terrorist

722.text:
attacks on UK soil.
Of course, I asked all the proper questions.

728.text:
How do we stop them? Is there another way?
Do we have that capability? Is it legal?

736.text:
I knew that whatever action I took would provoke
a big debate.

742.text:
But my job as Prime Minister is quite simple,
really: ultimately, it’s not to debate;

748.text:
it’s to decide.
And the choice I faced was this:

753.text:
Act – and we could stop them carrying out
their plans.

756.text:
Stall – and we could see innocent people
murdered on our streets.

760.text:
So I took decisive action to keep Britain
safe – and that’s what I will always do.

772.text:
LABOUR LEADER
And on the subject of protecting our country

789.text:
from terrorism, let me just say this:
Thousands of words have been written about

795.text:
the new Labour leader.
But you only really need to know one thing:

801.text:
he thinks the death of Osama bin Laden was
a “tragedy”.

807.text:
No.
A tragedy is nearly 3,000 people murdered

812.text:
one morning in New York.
A tragedy is the mums and dads who never came

817.text:
home from work that day.
A tragedy is people jumping from the towers

821.text:
after the planes hit.
My friends – we cannot let that man inflict

825.text:
his security-threatening, terrorist-sympathising,
Britain-hating ideology on the country we

858.text:
MIGRATION
Another big judgement call to make is when

871.text:
a refugee crisis confronts our world.
Like most people, I found it impossible to

878.text:
get the image of that poor Syrian boy Aylan
Kurdi out of my mind.

884.text:
We know in our hearts our responsibilities
to help those fleeing for their lives.

891.text:
But we know, too, that we must keep our heads.
Let’s start with a simple fact.

898.text:
Twelve million people have been made homeless
by the conflict in Syria. And so far only

903.text:
4 per cent of them have come to Europe.
If we opened the door to every refugee, our

909.text:
country would be overwhelmed.
The best thing Britain can do is help neighbouring

915.text:
countries, the Syrian people and the refugees
in the camps …

918.text:
…and when we do take refugees, to take them
from the region, rather than acting in a way

923.text:
that encourages more to make that dangerous
journey.

929.text:
As we do this, let’s remember: we haven’t
only just started caring about Syrians.

937.text:
We’ve been helping them over the past four
years, giving more in aid to that part of

943.text:
the world than any other country except America.
And we have been able to do that because this

959.text:
party made a promise and kept a promise – to
spend 0.7 per cent of our national income

966.text:
on aid.
Other countries also made that promise. But

970.text:
they didn’t keep it.
I say to them: if Britain can keep her promises,

975.text:
so should you.
But the real answer to the refugee crisis

988.text:
lies in helping countries like Syria become
places where people actually want to live.

994.text:
That means having a government that’s not
terrorising its people – and that’s why

998.text:
Assad must go.
In its place, we need a government that can

1002.text:
be our ally in the defeat of ISIL…
…because we will never be safe here in Britain

1008.text:
until we eradicate that death cult.
Some think we can contract that out to America.

1016.text:
We shouldn’t. We must play our part too.
And we can, because of that commitment we

1022.text:
made this summer: yes, we will spend two per
cent of our GDP on defence – this year,

1029.text:
next year, throughout this decade.
In the coming years, we’ll be launching

1046.text:
the biggest aircraft carriers in our history…
…a new class of Hunter Killer submarines…

1051.text:
…new Joint Strike Fighter jets; improved
Apache helicopters; a new fleet of drones…

1057.text:
…and because our independent nuclear deterrent
is our ultimate insurance policy – this

1063.text:
Government will order four new trident submarines.
In government, I have a team who keep us safe

1085.text:
at home and abroad…
…Justine Greening, Michael Fallon, Philip

1088.text:
Hammond and Theresa May.
But above all, we have Britain’s Armed Forces.

1094.text:
Let me tell you this:
In the last year alone they tackled Ebola

1099.text:
in West Africa; protected the skies over the
Baltic; flew missions over Iraq.

1104.text:
They built defences against ISIL in Lebanon;
trained army officers in Afghanistan; and

1109.text:
patrolled the seas around the Falklands.
There they were, in the Pacific, flying supplies

1114.text:
to cyclone victims; in the Atlantic, shipping
assistance to those hit by hurricanes; in

1120.text:
the Med, pulling people out of sinking dinghies.
Little England? No. Never.

1125.text:
Great Britain. And I’ll tell you what, with
Armed Forces like this, we can be even greater

1129.text:
still.
So let’s stand and thank them for everything

1142.text: they do to keep us safe.

1160.text:
EUROPE
A Greater Britain is one that is strong in

1165.text:
the world – and that should mean one that
is strong in Europe, too.

1170.text:
It comes back to those Conservative values:
our belief in the nation state, but also in

1176.text:
free trade.
We all know what’s wrong with the EU – it’s

1180.text:
got too big, too bossy, too interfering.
But we also know what’s right about it – it’s

1187.text:
the biggest single market in the world.
Now, some people say: “take what we’ve

1193.text:
got and put up with it”.
Others say: “just walk away from the whole

1197.text:
thing”.
I say: no. This is Britain. We don’t duck

1202.text:
fights. We get stuck in. We fix problems.
That’s how we kept our border checkpoints

1207.text:
when others decided to take theirs down.
It’s how we kept the pound when others went

1212.text:
head first into the Euro.
Because we do things our way.

1217.text:
We get rebates. We get out of bailouts.
But do you know what? It’s not just what

1223.text:
we get out of, it’s what we get Europe into.
Who do you think got Europe to open trade

1232.text:
talks with America, which would be the biggest
trade deal in our history?

1236.text:
Who do you think got Europe to agree to sanctions
on Iran, which brought that country to the

1241.text:
negotiating table?
Us. Britain. We did.

1246.text:
Believe me, I have no romantic attachment
to the European Union and its institutions.

1251.text:
I’m only interested in two things: Britain’s
prosperity and Britain’s influence.

1258.text:
That’s why I’m going to fight hard in
this renegotiation – so we can get a better

1263.text:
deal and the best of both worlds.
Let me give you one example.

1269.text:
When we joined the European Union we were
told that it was about going into a common

1273.text:
market, rather than the goal that some had
for “ever closer union”.

1278.text:
Let me put this very clearly: Britain is not
interested in “ever closer union” – and

1291.text:
ECONOMIC SECURITY
A Greater Britain needs a dynamic economy.

1303.text:
Today, it’s a beacon in an uncertain world…
…we’ve got more foreign investment flooding

1309.text:
into our country than anywhere else in Europe
– anywhere in the world except for America

1315.text:
and China.
But if anyone thinks the battle on the economy

1319.text:
is won, they need to think again. The battle
has only just begun.

1325.text:
We still need to find savings and produce
more; still need to become more competitive;

1331.text:
still need to make the most of our entire
country – and build the Northern Powerhouse.

1336.text:
And all at a time when our opponents have
given up any sensible, reasonable, rational

1344.text:
arguments on the economy.
We live in a country where the main opposition

1349.text:
party – let’s not forget, the alternative
government – believes in nationalising industries

1355.text:
without compensation, jacking up taxes to
60 per cent of people’s income, and printing

1361.text:
money.
There’s an academic called Richard Murphy.

1366.text:
He’s the Labour Party’s new economics
guru, and the man behind their plan to print

1372.text:
more money.
He gave an interview a few weeks ago. He was

1375.text:
very frank. He admitted that Labour’s plan
would cause a “sterling crisis”, but to

1385.text:
be fair…
…he did add, and I quote, that it “would

1389.text:
pass very quickly”.
Well, that’s alright then.

1392.text:
His book is actually called “The Joy of
Tax”. I’ve read it. It’s got 64 positions

1409.text:
– and they’re all wrong.
This is actually serious.

1426.text:
I tell you: our party’s success in growing
our economy and winning the economic arguments

1433.text:
has never been more vital.
Nothing less than the security of every single

1437.text:
family in our country depends on it.
And as we do that, I know that we will have

1442.text:
on our side not just the British people, not
just British business…

1448.text:
…but our Iron Chancellor, George Osborne.
You know what makes me most angry about Labour?

1467.text:
It’s not just that their arguments are wrong;
it’s the self-righteous way they make them.

1472.text:
The deficit-deniers, who go around saying
we’re hurting the poor.

1477.text:
Hang on a second.
Who gets hurt when governments lose control

1480.text:
of spending and interest rates go through
the roof?

1483.text:
Who gets hurt when you waste money on debt
interest and have to cut the NHS?

1488.text:
Who gets hurt when taxes go up and businesses
start firing rather than hiring?

1492.text:
No – not the rich…
…it’s poor people, working people.

1496.text:
Yes, the very people Labour claim to be for.
Well let’s just remember: Labour ideas don’t

1502.text:
help the poor, they hurt the poor.
That’s right, Labour: you’re not for working

1507.text:
people, but hurting people.
If you want a lecture about poverty, ask Labour.

1511.text:
If you want something done about it, come
to us, the Conservatives.

1528.text:
There’s another argument we need to win.
There are some people who understand the deficit

1548.text:
needs to come down, but don’t get why we
need a surplus.

1552.text:
I’ll tell you why.
I don’t stand here like a former Prime Minister

1558.text:
once did and say I have abolished boom and
bust.

1564.text:
We can’t just be thinking about today, we
should be thinking about the rainy days that

1569.text:
could come – just like a family does.
They put something aside, take out the insurance

1574.text:
plan, pay off some of the mortgage when they
have something spare.

1578.text:
That’s what we should do as a country – making
sure we are ready to cope with future crises.

1584.text:
There’s a word for those who say live for
today, forget about tomorrow: it’s selfish.

1592.text:
I’m not here to mortgage our children’s
future. I’m here to insure it.

1601.text:
HOME OWNERSHIP
But for me, there’s one big piece of unfinished

1611.text:
business in our economy: housing.
A Greater Britain must mean more families

1618.text:
owning a home of their own.
It goes back to those Conservative beliefs:

1623.text:
reward for hard work.
If you’ve worked hard and saved, I don’t

1627.text:
want you just to have a roof over your head
– I want you to have a roof of your own.

1632.text:
In the last 5 years, 600,000 new homes have
been built.

1637.text:
More than 150 people a day are moving in thanks
to our Help to Buy scheme.

1642.text:
And in our manifesto, we announced a breakthrough
policy: extending the Right to Buy to housing

1649.text:
association tenants.
Some people said this would be impossible.

1653.text:
Housing associations would never stand for
it. The legislation would never pass.

1657.text:
Let me tell you something.
Greg Clark, our brilliant Communities Secretary,

1662.text:
has secured a deal with housing associations
to give their tenants the Right to Buy their

1667.text:
home.
That will mean the first tenants can start

1670.text:
to buy their homes from next year.
Yes, as we said in our manifesto, 1.3 million

1677.text:
to be given the chance to become homeowners.
A promise made. A promise kept.

1693.text:
But the challenge is far, far bigger.
When a generation of hardworking men and women

1698.text:
in their 20s and 30s are waking up each morning
in their childhood bedrooms – that should

1704.text:
be a wakeup call for us.
We need a national crusade to get homes built.

1711.text:
That means banks lending, government releasing
land, and yes – planning being reformed.

1716.text:
And in all these things I’ll be working
with a great London Mayoral candidate – and,

1721.text:
I hope, soon to be our London Mayor – Zac
Goldsmith.

1735.text:
But I want to single someone out. He’s served
this country. He’s served this party. And

1741.text:
there’s a huge amount more to come.
So let’s hear it for the man who for two

1746.text:
terms has been Mayor of the greatest capital
city on earth: Boris Johnson.

1810.text:
Increasing home ownership means something
else.

1812.text:
For years, politicians have been talking about
building what they call “affordable homes”

1818.text:
– but the phrase was deceptive.
It basically meant homes that were only available

1824.text:
to rent. What people want are homes they can
actually own.

1830.text:
After all, the officials who prepare the plans
for the new homes, the developers who build

1834.text:
them, the politicians who talk about them…
…most of these people own the homes they

1838.text:
live in.
Don’t they realise other people want what

1841.text:
they’ve got – a home of their own?
So today, I can announce a dramatic shift

1853.text:
in housing policy in our country.
Those old rules which said to developers:

1858.text:
you can build on this site, but only if you
build affordable homes for rent…

1863.text:
…we’re replacing them with new rules…
…you can build here, and those affordable

1868.text:
homes can be available to buy.
Yes, from Generation Rent to Generation Buy…

1873.text:
…our party, the Conservative party…
…the party of home ownership in Britain

1882.text:
SOCIAL REFORM
A more prosperous Britain.

1895.text:
But we must not stop there as we build a Greater
Britain.

1899.text:
We are not a one-trick party.
For us, economic success – that’s not

1904.text:
the finished article.
It’s the foundation on which we can build

1909.text:
a better society.
Our patriotism has never been simply some

1913.text:
grand notion of ruling the waves, or riding
high in the money markets…

1917.text:
…but a deep compulsion which says: “you
make a country greater by making life better

1923.text:
for its people.”
And today, that means entering those no-go

1928.text:
zones, where politicians often don’t dare
to venture.

1932.text:
It means taking on our big social problems…
…entrenched poverty, blocked opportunity,

1937.text:
the extremism that blights our communities.
Why?

1942.text:
So when the new mum looks at her new-born
baby – the most precious thing she’s ever

1946.text:
seen – and she vows to provide for it, she
knows she actually can.

1951.text:
When the schoolgirl sits in that classroom,
she knows that her studies really can take

1956.text:
her to the very top.
When the child of immigrants sees our flag,

1961.text:
he feels so loyal to this country – his
country – he wants to put on a uniform and

1966.text:
defend it.
That is what fires me up. Not pounds and pence,

1969.text:
plans and policies, but people.
And to those who say: our social problems

1976.text:
are too big and there’s no way you can sort
them out.

1978.text:
I say: You said our party wouldn’t change
– we have.

1983.text:
You said our long-term economic plan wouldn’t
work – it is.

1986.text:
You said we wouldn’t win the election – we
did.

1988.text:
So we are going to tackle those big social
problems – just you watch us.

2001.text:
POVERTY
Central to that is an all-out assault on poverty.

2014.text:
Conservatives understand that if we’re serious
about solving the problem, we need to tackle

2018.text:
the root causes of poverty.
Homes where no-one works; children growing

2024.text:
up in chaos; addiction, mental health problems,
abuse, family breakdown.

2030.text:
Today, a teenager sitting their GCSEs is more
likely to own a smartphone than have a dad

2038.text:
living with them.
Think of your own child, think of the day

2044.text:
they were born; how fragile they were…
…and then think that, every day, three babies

2051.text:
are born in Britain addicted to heroin.
We’ll never deal with poverty unless we

2058.text:
get to grips with these issues.
We made a start in the last five years with

2063.text:
our Troubled Families programme.
It’s already turned around the lives of

2066.text:
over 100,000 families.
And do you know one of its central aims?

2071.text:
It’s simple: get the adults a job.
Because we know in this party that the best

2076.text:
route out of poverty is work.
That’s why we reformed welfare, introduced

2081.text:
the cap and helped create 2.5 million jobs.
But it’s not enough simply to have a job:

2088.text:
work has got to pay.
Nearly two-thirds of children in poverty have

2093.text:
parents who are in jobs. For them, work hasn’t
worked.

2098.text:
That’s why we’ve cut taxes for the lowest
paid and we’ll keep on doing that.

2103.text:
And from next year, we’ll take a giant leap
forward.

2106.text:
Yes, a new National Living Wage.
Over £9 an hour by the end of the decade.

2112.text:
An £80-a-week pay rise for the lowest paid.
Work paying for millions of people.

2119.text:
So let the message go out: if you work hard,
want to get on, want more money at the end

2124.text:
of the month…
…the party for you is right here in this

2128.text:
hall.
But being out of work is only one of the causes

2147.text:
we must tackle.
Children in care are today almost guaranteed

2153.text:
to live in poverty.
84 per cent leave school without five good

2159.text:
GCSEs.
70 per cent of prostitutes were once in care.

2166.text:
And tragically, care leavers are four times
more likely to commit suicide than anyone

2172.text:
else.
These children are in our care; we, the state,

2179.text:
are their parents – and what are we setting
them up for…

2183.text:
…the dole, the streets, an early grave?
I tell you: this shames our country and we

2189.text:
will put it right.
Just as we said to failing schools, “do

2195.text:
a better job with our children or we will
send new leaders in”, so we will say to

2199.text:
poorly performing social services, “improve
or be taken over”.

2214.text:
got the best graduates teaching at our most
difficult schools, let’s get our brightest

2221.text:
and best to the frontline of social work.
But we must also stop children needing to

2229.text:
be in care at all.
When we came to office, the adoption rate

2233.text:
in our country was frankly a scandal.
It has gone up. Our Adoption Bill will help

2238.text:
it increase still further.
But there’s so much more to do.

2243.text:
So let us in this hall say to all those children
desperate for a family, and all those families

2248.text:
yearning for a child:
We, the Conservatives, we are the ones who

2253.text:
will bring you together.
There’s another service run by the state

2268.text:
that all too often fails and entrenches poverty.
Prison.

2273.text:
Now I believe if you’ve committed a crime,
punishment must follow.

2278.text:
And when it’s serious enough, that punishment
must mean prison.

2283.text:
Let’s not forget, since we came to office,
crime is down by a quarter.

2288.text:
But the system is still not working.
Half of criminals offend within a year of

2293.text:
being released.
Nearly half go into prison with no qualifications;

2298.text:
many come out with none either.
And all the problems that may have led them

2302.text:
to that life – drug addiction, mental health
problems, childhood abuse – remain unchanged.

2310.text:
We have got to get away from the sterile lock-em-up
or let-em-out debate, and get smart about

2316.text:
this.
When prisoners are in jail, we have their

2319.text:
full attention for months at a time – so
let’s treat their problems, educate them,

2324.text:
put them to work.
When we restrict someone’s freedom outside

2328.text:
prison, we can make sure they’re working
and paying taxes, rather than spending £30,000

2333.text:
a year keeping them in a cell – so where
it makes sense, let’s use electronic tags

2339.text:
to help keep us safe and help people go clean.
And when our prisons are relics from the time

2346.text:
of Dickens – it’s time to sell them off
and build new ones that actually work.

2361.text:
This is going to be a big area of social reform
in the next five years. And I have just the

2366.text:
man for the job.
The man who takes on every vested interest

2369.text:
and gives everyone a chance…
…the man who began the great transformation

2373.text:
of our education system and is now going to
do the same for prisons…

2377.text:
…yes, the great Conservative reformer, Michael
Gove.

2385.text:
OPPORTUNITY
If we tackle the causes of poverty, we can

2397.text:
make our country greater.
But there’s another big social problem we

2402.text:
need to fix.
In politicians’ speak: a “lack of social

2406.text:
mobility”.
In normal language: people unable to rise

2410.text:
from the bottom to the top, or even from the
middle to the top, because of their background.

2416.text:
Listen to this: Britain has the lowest social
mobility in the developed world.

2423.text:
Here, the salary you earn is more linked to
what your father got paid than in any other

2430.text:
major country.
I’m sorry, for us Conservatives, the party

2435.text:
of aspiration, we cannot accept that.
We know that education is the springboard

2440.text:
to opportunity.
Our reforms are already working.

2444.text:
More children studying maths and science.
More learning coding and engineering. More

2449.text:
doing the extra-curricular activities that
teach confidence and build character.

2453.text:
Recently, I was at a school in Runcorn. Last
year, 53 of their children went off to university.

2462.text:
52 of them were the first ever in their family
to do so.

2465.text:
That is why I’m so passionate about academies
and free schools:

2469.text:
Head teachers are growing in confidence as
they throw off the shackles of local council

2474.text:
control…
…raising the aspirations of children, parents,

2479.text:
communities.
This movement is sweeping across our country.

2482.text:
So my next ambition is this.
500 new Free Schools.

2487.text:
Every school an academy…
…and yes – Local Authorities running schools

2491.text:
a thing of the past.
But let’s be honest.

2508.text:
For too many people, even a good education
isn’t enough.

2512.text:
There are other barriers that stand in their
way.

2516.text:
Picture this.
You’ve graduated with a good degree.

2522.text:
You send out your CV far and wide.
But you get rejection after rejection.

2527.text:
What’s wrong? It’s not the qualifications
or the previous experience.

2533.text:
It’s just two words at the top: first name,
surname.

2539.text:
Do you know that in our country today: even
if they have exactly the same qualifications,

2544.text:
people with white-sounding names are nearly
twice as likely to get call backs for jobs

2550.text:
than people with ethnic-sounding names?
This is a true story.

2555.text:
One young black girl had to change her name
to Elizabeth before she got any calls to interviews.

2561.text:
That, in 21st century Britain, is disgraceful.
We

2577.text:
can talk all we want about opportunity, but
it’s meaningless unless people are really

2583.text:
judged equally.
Think about it like this.

2588.text:
Opportunity doesn’t mean much to a British
Muslim if he walks down the street and is

2592.text:
abused for his faith.
Opportunity doesn’t mean much to a black

2596.text:
person constantly stopped and searched by
the police because of the colour of their

2601.text:
skin.
Opportunity doesn’t mean much to a gay person

2604.text:
rejected for a job because of the person they
love.

2606.text:
It doesn’t mean much to a disabled person
prevented from doing what they’re good at

2611.text:
because of who they are.
I’m a dad of two daughters – opportunity

2615.text:
won’t mean anything to them if they grow
up in a country where they get paid less because

2618.text:
of their gender rather than how good they
are at their work.

2621.text:
The point is this: you can’t have true opportunity
without real equality.

2639.text:
And I want our party to get this right.
Yes us, the party of the fair chance; the

2646.text:
party of the equal shot…
…the party that doesn’t care where you

2649.text:
come from, but only where you’re going…
…us, the Conservatives, I want us to end

2654.text:
discrimination and finish the fight for real
equality in our country today.

2674.text:
EXTREMISM
Tackling the causes of poverty. Fighting for

2693.text:
real opportunity.
And there’s one more big social reform in

2698.text:
our mission to rebuild Britain as an even
greater country.

2703.text:
We need to confront – and I mean really
confront – extremism.

2710.text:
When I read what some young people born and
brought up in this country are doing, it makes

2716.text:
me feel sick to my stomach.
Girls not much older than my eldest daughter,

2722.text:
swapping loving family homes and straight-A
futures for a life of servitude under ISIL,

2728.text:
in a land of violence and oppression.
Boys who could do anything they wanted in

2734.text:
Britain – who have benefitted from all this
country stands for – instead ending up in

2739.text:
the desert wielding a knife.
This ideology, this diseased view of the world,

2746.text:
has become an epidemic – infecting minds
from the mosques of Mogadishu to the bedrooms

2752.text:
of Birmingham.
And here’s what we need to do.

2757.text:
One: tear up the narrative that says Muslims
are persecuted and the West deserves what

2763.text:
it gets.
Never mind that it’s Britain and America

2766.text:
behind the biggest effort to help the victims
of Syria.

2769.text:
Who is ISIL murdering more than anyone else?
Muslims.

2773.text:
No-one should get away with this politics
of grievance anymore.

2782.text:
Two: take on extremism in all its forms, the
violent and non-violent.

2795.text:
People don’t become terrorists from a standing
start.

2800.text:
It begins with preachers telling them that
Christians and Muslims can’t live together.

2805.text:
It moves to people in their community saying
the security services were responsible for

2810.text:
7/7.
It progresses to a website telling them how

2814.text:
to wage jihad, fight in Syria, and defeat
the West.

2817.text:
And before you know it, a young British boy,
barely 17, is strapping bombs to his body

2824.text:
and blowing himself up in Iraq.
We have to stop it at the start – stop this

2829.text:
seed of hatred even being planted in people’s
minds, let alone allowing it to grow.

2835.text:
Three: we need to tackle segregation.
There are parts of Britain today where you

2843.text:
can get by without ever speaking English or
meeting anyone from another culture.

2848.text:
Zoom in and you’ll see some institutions
that actually help incubate these divisions.

2855.text:
Did you know, in our country, there are some
children who spend several hours each day

2861.text:
at a Madrassa?
Let me be clear: there is nothing wrong with

2865.text:
children learning about their faith, whether
it’s at Madrassas, Sunday Schools or Jewish

2871.text:
Yeshivas.
But in some Madrassas we’ve got children

2875.text:
being taught that they shouldn’t mix with
people of other religions; being beaten; swallowing

2880.text:
conspiracy theories about Jewish people.
These children should be having their minds

2885.text:
opened, their horizons broadened…
…not having their heads filled with poison

2888.text:
and their hearts filled with hate.
So I can announce this today:

2906.text:
If an institution is teaching children intensively,
then whatever its religion, we will, like

2912.text:
any other school, make it register so it can
be inspected.

2917.text:
And be in no doubt: if you are teaching intolerance,
we will shut you down.

2936.text:
This goes to a wider truth.
For too long, we’ve been so frightened of

2941.text:
causing offence that we haven’t looked hard
enough at what is going on in our communities.

2948.text:
This is passive tolerance. And I’ll tell
you where it leads:

2954.text:
To children, British children, going to Pakistan
in the summer holidays, before they’ve even

2958.text:
started their GCSEs, and forced to marry a
man they’ve never met…

2963.text:
…children, British children, having their
genitals mutilated, not just in a clinic in

2968.text:
Lagos but the backstreets in Britain.
This passive tolerance has turned us into

2973.text:
a less integrated country; it’s put our
children in danger. It is unforgivable.

2978.text:
So let me say it right here: no more passive
tolerance in Britain.

2986.text:
We’ve passed the laws – now I want them
enforced.

3012.text:
People who organise forced marriages – I
want them prosecuted.

3016.text:
Parents who take their children for FGM – I
want them arrested.

3019.text:
And as we do that, we shouldn’t just be
saying what’s wrong with these practices;

3025.text:
we should be saying what’s right with Britain.
Freedom. Democracy. Equality. These are precious.

3031.text:
People fought for them – many died for them…
…in the trenches, a century ago; on the

3035.text:
beaches, 30 years later…
…in the Suffragettes; in Gay Pride.

3040.text:
Half the world is crying out for these freedoms
– they see what we’ve achieved with them.

3045.text:
Free speech – and the best literature in
the world.

3049.text:
Freedom of religion – and many faiths living
side by side, peacefully.

3054.text:
Free thinking – and the endless advances
in medicine and technology that has brought.

3058.text:
A free economy – and a standard of living
our grandparents could only have dreamed of.

3064.text:
I want my children – I want all our children
– to know they’re part of something big

3067.text:
– the proudest multi-racial democracy on
earth.

3071.text:
That’s why we’re making sure they learn
British history at school.

3081.text:
That’s why we started National Citizen Service
to bring different people together.

3091.text:
I want them to grow up proud of our country.
That’s right: less Britain-bashing, more

3096.text:
national pride – our way, the Conservative
way, the only way to greater days.

3107.text:
CONSERVATIVES
So big battles. Big arguments. A Greater Britain.

3120.text:
Keeping our head as Labour lose theirs.
So I have a message for those who voted for

3124.text:
us and those who never have:
If you believe in strong defence, and helping

3130.text:
the poorest, most desperate people in the
world.

3133.text:
If you want an NHS that’s there for everybody,
and schools that stretch our children…

3137.text:
…and you understand none of that is possible
without a strong economy.

3142.text:
If you believe we can become the enterprise
capital of the world and beat poverty.

3147.text:
If you believe that the fight against extremism
is the fight for our existence; and you want

3152.text:
this to be the generation that ends discrimination.
If you want these things, the party you need

3159.text:
is the party right here.
And it’s never too late.

3164.text:
Bernard Harris from Leicester wrote to me
before polling day and said this.

3169.text:
“Aged 82, this is possibly my last election.
“In my life I have foolishly voted Labour,

3177.text:
believing it served the working class.
“How wrong I was. Labour is against all

3183.text:
I aspire to.
“I am 100 per cent for a United Kingdom,

3188.text:
a sound economy, free enterprise, a trading
Europe and a decent standard of living.

3193.text:
“Only a Conservative Government will achieve
this.”

3196.text:
Bernard, you found the right party – and
I want many more to follow in your footsteps.

3205.text:
CONCLUSION
So I believe that we can make this era – these

3217.text:
2010s – a defining decade for our country…
…the turnaround decade…

3222.text:
…one which people will look back on and
say: “that’s the time when the tide turned…

3227.text:
…when people no longer felt the current
going against them, but working with them.”

3233.text:
We can be that Greater Britain.
Because we know this: nothing is written.

3238.text:
We’ve proved it in schools across our country…
…that the poorest children don’t have

3242.text:
to get the worst results – they can get
the best.

3245.text:
Over the next five years we will show that
the deep problems in our society – they

3249.text:
are not inevitable.
That a childhood in care doesn’t have to

3252.text:
mean a life of struggle.
That a stint in prison doesn’t mean you’ll

3256.text:
get out and do the same thing all over again.
That being black, or Asian, or female, or

3261.text:
gay doesn’t mean you’ll be treated differently.
Nothing is written.

3265.text:
And if we’re to be the global success story
of the 21st century, we need to write millions

3270.text:
of individual success stories.
A Greater Britain – made of greater expectations…

3280.text:
…a small island becomes an even bigger economy…
…and where extremism is defeated once and

3288.text:
…no more, its people dragged down or held
back…

3291.text:
…no more, some children with their noses
pressed to the window as they watch the world

3295.text:
moving ahead without them.
No – a country raising its sights, its people

3300.text:
reaching new heights…
…a Great British take-off – that leaves

3303.text:
no-one behind.
That’s our dream – to help you realise

3306.text:
your dreams.
A Greater Britain – made of greater hope,

3309.text:
greater chances, greater security.
So let’s get out there – all of us – and
